content.title: Theoretical Minimum Velocity
content.abstract: Velocity is a continuous quantity with no theoretical minimum - zero velocity (being at rest) is perfectly valid. Unlike speed of light as a maximum, there is no analogous minimum for velocity in either classical or quantum physics.

theoretical_minimum.status: NO MINIMUM - continuous from 0 to c

massive_particles.maximum: v < c (can approach but never reach)

massless_particles.cannot_be_slower: Photons always travel at c in vacuum

quantum_mechanics.uncertainty_implication: If position is uncertain, velocity distribution is nonzero
quantum_mechanics.zero_velocity_eigenstate: Free particle with v = 0 has infinite position uncertainty
quantum_mechanics.confined_particle: Even at ground state, velocity fluctuates (zero-point motion)

velocity_in_materials.can_be_very_slow: Slow light experiments: v ~ 17 m/s achieved
velocity_in_materials.stopped_light: Light can be 'stopped' (v → 0) in special media (EIT)
velocity_in_materials.cherenkov_radiation: Particles can exceed v = c/n in medium

planck_velocity.note: Planck velocity equals c - it's a maximum, not minimum
planck_velocity.significance: c is the universal speed limit

comparison_with_other_quantities.position: No theoretical minimum (x can be anywhere)
